title: Algorithms for Quantum Computation: Discrete Logarithms and Factoring
abstract: A computer is generally considered to be a universal computational device; i.e., it is believed able to simulate any physical computational device with a cost in computation time of at most a polynomial factor. This paper considers factoring integers and finding discrete logarithms, two problems which are generally thought to be hard on a classical computer and have been used as the basis of several proposed cryptosystems. Efficient randomized algorithms are given for these two problems on a hypothetical quantum computer.

title: Quantum Cryptography: Public Key Distribution and Coin Tossing
abstract: When elementary quantum systems, such as polarized photons, are used to transmit digital information, the uncertainty principle gives rise to novel cryptographic phenomena unachievable with traditional transmission media. This paper describes a method for public key distribution using quantum communication that is provably secure against eavesdropping.

title: Post-Quantum Cryptography
abstract: This comprehensive survey introduces the reader to the next generation of cryptographic algorithms, designed to resist attacks by both classical and quantum computers. Topics covered include lattice-based cryptography, code-based cryptography, hash-based signatures, and multivariate cryptography.

title: CRYSTALS-Kyber: A CCA-Secure Module-Lattice-Based KEM
abstract: We introduce Kyber, a portfolio of post-quantum cryptographic primitives built around a key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM). Our construction is based on the hardness of the Module Learning with Errors (MLWE) problem and is designed to be secure against attacks by quantum computers. Kyber was selected by NIST for standardization as ML-KEM.

title: CRYSTALS-Dilithium: A Lattice-Based Digital Signature Scheme
abstract: Dilithium is a digital signature scheme that is strongly secure under chosen message attacks based on the hardness of lattice problems over module lattices. It was designed for the NIST Post-Quantum Cryptography standardization project and has been selected as ML-DSA for standardization.

title: Quantum Computing: Progress and Prospects
authors: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine
abstract: This report assesses the current state of quantum computing and identifies the technical challenges that must be overcome to develop a practical quantum computer capable of breaking current cryptographic systems. It examines the timeline for cryptographically relevant quantum computers and the urgency of transitioning to post-quantum cryptography.

title: Grover's Algorithm and Its Application to Cryptanalysis
abstract: This paper describes a quantum mechanical algorithm for searching an unsorted database of N entries in O(√N) time. When applied to cryptographic systems, Grover's algorithm effectively halves the security level of symmetric key algorithms like AES, requiring a doubling of key sizes to maintain equivalent security against quantum attacks.

title: SPHINCS+: Stateless Hash-Based Signatures
abstract: SPHINCS+ is a stateless hash-based signature scheme designed to provide post-quantum security based solely on the security of hash functions. Selected by NIST as SLH-DSA, it offers a conservative approach to quantum-resistant signatures with well-understood security assumptions.

title: Quantum Threat Timeline Report
abstract: Annual survey of quantum computing experts assessing the likelihood and timeline for the development of cryptographically relevant quantum computers. The report analyzes expert opinions on when quantum computers will be capable of breaking RSA-2048 and similar public-key cryptosystems.

title: Harvest Now, Decrypt Later: The Threat of Store-Now-Decrypt-Later Attacks
abstract: This paper analyzes the 'harvest now, decrypt later' threat where adversaries collect encrypted data today with the intention of decrypting it once sufficiently powerful quantum computers become available. The analysis emphasizes the urgency of migrating to quantum-resistant cryptography for data with long-term confidentiality requirements.

title: Status Report on the Third Round of the NIST Post-Quantum Cryptography Standardization Process
abstract: This report describes the evaluation and selection process for the NIST Post-Quantum Cryptography standardization project. It announces the selection of CRYSTALS-Kyber for key encapsulation and CRYSTALS-Dilithium, FALCON, and SPHINCS+ for digital signatures as algorithms to be standardized.

title: Quantum-Safe Cryptography: Securing Today's Data for Tomorrow
abstract: This report provides guidance on the transition to quantum-safe cryptography for organizations and governments. It covers the quantum threat landscape, post-quantum cryptographic solutions, migration strategies, and recommendations for achieving crypto-agility.
